results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows the Malins family in a montage of holidays and events in Victoria spanning several years from 1946 to the 1950s (not in precise chronological order). Highlights include a visit to Melbourne Zoo, trips to the beach along the Great Ocean Road and to Phillip Island, as well as trips to the snow at Lake Mountain. Malins frequently captured road signs of their travel destinations, including Anglesea, Lorne, Wye River and Cowes. Other moments captured include children’s birthday parties, horse riding and children at school (possibly Koonung Heights Primary School in Mont Albert North, 1954–1993).

The film also features footage of an historic gathering at the Shrine of Remembrance on the occasion of Field Marshal Bernard Law Montgomery’s visit to Melbourne in 1947.

Selected highlights (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:02:00 (upside down footage) caged orangutan at Zoo eating an ice cream
00:00:15:00 entrance to Melbourne Zoo
00:00:20:00 visitor hands food to a white-cheeked gibbon through cage fence
00:00:29:00 George, Sybil, Helen and John picnic on lawn, with the Taggart family
00:00:45:00 children ride the open-carriage train, ‘Zoo Spirit of Progress’ written on side of driver’s car (a reference to Victorian Railways premier express train from Melbourne to Albury)
00:01:07:00 children riding on an Indian Elephant
00:01:15:00 horse performing tricks for audience, balancing on a see-saw, riding and bucking in the arena with a baboon (possibly a hamadryas baboon) on back
00:01:40:00 George, Sybil, Helen and John with Mabel Malins (Nana) having a picnic with fire next to river, great shots of family members eating and smiling, at Healesville Sanctuary
00:02:40:00 Children play in yard. One boy wearing an ‘indian’ costume rides a tricycle; another boy rides a rocking horse; two girls push prams with dolls. Christmas morning at Rathmines Road, Hawthorn.
00:03:20:00 children and mother in caravan trailer, portable radio, bicycle and a 1940s Chevrolet Utility vehicle (Ute)
00:03:48:00 road sign ‘Anglesea – please slow down’
00:04:09:00 ‘Great Ocean Road’ Memorial Arch
00:04:25:00 road sign ‘Lorne – please slow down’
00:04:28:00 children walking in water and climbing on rocks at the beach
00:05:02:00 Sybil and girl standing next to road sign ‘Wye River’ at bridge
00:05:11:00 boy playing with toy boat in water
00:05:17:00 group of children paddling a yellow inflatable dinghy
00:05:51:00 John holding a small fish that he caught
00:05:59:00 gathering of families, playing games on beach
00:06:29:00 two children in bath, Helen and John
00:07:00:00 family, including Mabel Malins, celebrating Helen’s sixth birthday with cake at dining table
00:07:25:00 family in snow with sled, having a snowball fight at Lake Mountain
00:08:35:00 Helen and John at horse-riding school on country road. A man and a boy pass by standing on the back of a flatbed ute.
00:08:58:00 children ride in a horse drawn cart with a crop harvest (possibly corn)
00:09:07:00 group of nurses surround new born baby, Ruth, as she leaves hospital. Ethel Taggart briefly pictured.
00:09:17:00 people riding horses across country road
00:09:35:00 baby (Ruth) amused by family members at Whitehorse Road, Balwyn
00:10:36:00 baby hops and slides along the floor
00:10:55:00 family exiting St Mark’s Church Camberwell in formal clothing, after Ruth’s chistening; priest holding baby
00:11:41:00 John and Helen walking Ruth (toddler) in harness at Doncaster Road; John wearing leg braces
00:12:11:00 children riding on carousel at San Remo
00:12:39:00 John pushing Ruth in swing; John wearing leg calipers
00:12:56:00 John presented with the dux award at a school, Balwyn Primary School
00:13:13:00 family playing tennis-like game at Wye River beach; Mabs, Ruth and Janet playing with sand
00:13:45:00 in a lounge room, next to a fireplace, George and Sybil and their two daughters throw beach balls to each other (217 Doncaster Road with Bill Gladstone, Ruth and Janet)
00:14:20:00 intertitle card “Wake’y Wake’y”: a day in the life of Ruth and Janet
00:15:33:00 Ruth and Janet holding toys, a baby doll and a plush dog
00:15:45:00 intertitle card “Breakfast”
00:16:10:00 intertitle card “Off to School”: Sybil waving goodbye to her daughters who leave the home with their ports (small briefcases)
00:16:26:00 the girls running through a playground
00:16:39:00 intertitle card “Assembly”: outdoor gathering of students standing in line formations, hand on heart
00:17:16:00 students march into classrooms; crates of glass milk bottles stacked outside one classroom
00:17:46:00 Australian flag blowing in the wind
00:17:54:00 intertitle cards “Forestry Commission’s Lecture”; “Arbor Day at Koonung School 1956”
00:18:10:00 intertitle card “Mr. Godfrey – Our Headmaster”
00:18:26:00 intertitle card “Frances, Joanne and Janet Planting a Tree”
00:18:51:00 adults and children watch as children plant trees (excellent example of 1950s fashion)
00:19:00:00 classroom puppet show, children performing a song and dance for parents
00:20:10:00 girl writing in book at a wooden desk; the desks have ink bottle holders
00:20:30:00 group of children dancing in formation outside
00:21:50:00 Janet’s 6th birthday party: hildren wearing homemade party hats with blowers, sit around a cake and snack spread
00:22:17:00 Nan, Ruth and Janet at the Nobbies Phillip Island, then riding wooden belly boards at Wye River with Dora Kennedy and son John
00:22:58:00 girl and dog climbing on rocks at beach
00:23:03:00 young man fishing from rocks at beach
00:23:11:00 family takes shelter under rocks
00:23:23:00 family riding inflatable dinghy in the Yarra River, Warrandyte
00:24:11:00 koala sitting in and climbing a tree
00:24:23:00 road sign ‘Cowes – please slow down’
00:24:28:00 crossing the wooden bridge to Phillip Island
00:25:21:00 men playing golf in Apollo Bay next to beach, with boats and distant landscape in background
00:25:30:00 putting on golf green
00:25:58:00 “C.O.R.” written on a weathervane
00:26:02:00 Pontiac driving on Great Ocean Road, with wide shot of hillside coastline
00:26:51:00 car bogged on a snow covered road, people attempt to release it
00:27:02:00 children having a snowball fight
00:27:13:00 people make a snowman, dressed with a hat, scarf and buttons
00:27:38:00 riding sleds down a snow covered hill
00:28:32:00 wide shot of tree covered mountains and valleys
00:29:06:00 large group of children and adults riding horses in country location
00:29:59:00 large gathering of people at Shrine of Remembrance; soldier marches across the front of shrine
00:30:22:00 soldiers wearing slouch hats marching toward the shrine; the reflecting pool (removed in the early 1950s) is partially shown with Melbourne skyline in distance
00:30:37:00 Highly decorated men in uniform gather. Man wearing black beret is Field Marshal Bernard Law Montgomery, 1st Viscount Montgomery of Alamein. His presence places this footage in 1947. Surrounded by enormous crowd of people, including police officers wearing a black bobby helmet.
00:31:10:00 family in Chevrolet Ute with caravan trailer
00:31:28:00 family at beach dressed in skirts made of newspaper, bows and flowers in hair; men wearing stuffed brassieres perform a dance
00:32:05:00 people catching waves, riding wooden belly boards
00:32:34:00 Australian National Airways plane (possibly a Douglas DC-4), ‘Bungana’ written on exterior of cockpit. Propellers start to spin, plane moves.
00:33:03:00 Ansett Airways plane (possibly a Douglas DC-3), turns on tarmac
00:33:06:00 man on horse in residential area, Bulleen Riding School
00:33:10:00 fancy dress party at 217 Doncaster Road; children in costumes (yellow bird and nurse) in yard at “Heath’s home”
00:33:22:00 large gathering of children and women at Wattle Park with picnic baskets (Janet’s kindergarten)

results.title: [Remix: The Races]
results.creator_credit: Dakota Henderson, ACMI Collections and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This short remix of films about horse racing set to music, takes you through from getting ready and arriving at the track, to placing a bet, the race and the result.

This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to some of the activities around the spring racing carnival that takes place in Melbourne during October and November. It captures the race preparations for both people and horses, and shows the mounting yard, the TAB bets, the race call and a punter finding out the winner.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge donor: Ivan Gaal ( Dir., ‘The Punter’, 1978).

results.title: Glimpses of Australia. [No. 01] [excerpt]
results.brief_description:
Spare a thought for yesteryear as you battle your way through peak hour. This except is from taken from a Commonwealth Government newsreel made in the 1920s. It has been digitised from a 16mm film print and digitally stabilised to improve viewing.
This segment has the intertitle “Melbourne” and shows Melbourne CBD, Flinders St Station, Collins St, trams, trains and Parliament House.

results.title: [Remix: ACMI Collection 2]
results.brief_description:
This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to the gems in the ACMI Collection. A remix of home movies and short works from the collection featuring elements on ‘how a movie is made’ and a split screen collage of moving images, interspersed with intertitles. The work was initially designed as part of a fundraising campaign.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Australian Dried Fruits Association; John Richardson; Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office; Ivan Gaal; Wine Australia and Tony Agapitos.

results.title: [Remix: Strike A Pose]
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, ACMI Collections and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to people posing for the camera. A remix of home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection featuring families, fashion models and even a dog, all striking a pose for the camera. On a fashion catwalk, in a parade, on a photoshoot, in a factory or outdoor setting or just the back yard, fashionistas and family folk put their best foot forward from the 1940s to 1970s.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Dried Fruits Australia, Karen Wootton, Elenor Peach, Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office, Jenny & Owen Peake, Tony Agapitos and Ivan Gaal.

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film captures a major event in the lives of the Nixon family – daughter Karen’s wedding. The fashion on the day is a wonderful example of the late 1980s and the bridesmaids wear Karen’s favourite colour, red. Karen’s new family, the Corrys, are in the film having visited from the UK.

Of interest in this film, when Karen arrives at the church there are many onlookers who are there but are not guests. At this period of time it was still customary, particularly in country areas, for members of the community to come along to watch the bridal party arrive and leave the church.

Later we see Karen preparing to leave for overseas possibly to Indonesia as we view a Garuda airplane from what appears to be the Observation Deck at Tullamarine Airport, Melbourne, when it was still open.

This film also contains scenes of a new kitten in the family, inside the house and in the yard chasing a rope hanging from the clothes line.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 Karen in a 1980s style wedding dress and her bridesmaids dressed in red, are relaxed for the camera in the family lounge room and outside on the terrace
00:01:15:00 the bridal party arrives at the church among a group of interested onlookers
00:01:24:00 father Les and daughter Karen pose for the camera alongside the bridal car
00:01:35:00 the bride and groom exchange rings inside the church (quite dark and grainy)
00:02:00:00 the bridal party pose for the camera, the men showing off some wonderful 1980s moustaches
00:02:42:00 the Nixon parents and the Corry parents gather with the bride and groom for a group photo
00:03:20:00 a family gathering in the backyard of the Geelong family home after the wedding
00:03:39:00 Dorothy, mother of the bride and always stylish, wearing a good example of a 1980s sundress in pink with black dots
00:04:16:00 having fun: a member of the family poses in a ‘Foster’s Lager’ singlet whilst drinking a ‘Foster’s Lager’ before then posing with a ‘beer gut’ shape for the camera
00:06:39:00 another family wedding where Karen is an attendant
00:07:22:00 a sign outside the church which states, ‘Do Not Drop Confetti’
00:09:35:00 Karen and her husband relaxed in front of the camera in the church grounds
00:12:40:00 a family gathering in the backyard
00:13:42:00 Karen packing for travel in front of a Christmas tree where a kitten is playing
00:14:23:00 a set Christmas table and then the family seated at the table except for Les who is filming
00:14:55:00 Karen checking in at the airport
00:15:54:00 airplanes on the tarmac being filmed from the rooftop Observation Deck at Melbourne Airport
00:19:50:00 after many scenes of playing, we see an exhausted kitten asleep in a cardboard box

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film begins with Dorothy, Karen and Stuart relaxing around the family Christmas tree, 1984 and moves onto family activities in the backyard. There are two extended family weddings and some wonderful fashion from the early 1980s.

The highlight of the film is Karen’s 21st birthday where we see the traditional table for the presents to be displayed before Karen proudly poses for the camera in front of her new car.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 Dorothy, Karen and Stuart chatting, whilst seated around their Christmas tree at home
00:00:23:00 Karen in some fantastic embroidered trousers with a boyfriend, Dorothy and Stuart in the garden at home
00:00:35:00 family barbeque in the backyard
00:00:53:00 classic 1970s and 1980s style glassware
00:02:33:00 ‘totem’ tennis being played in the backyard
00:02:50:00 Stuart and a friend or cousin being rallied to pose for the camera
00:04:23:00 large family gathering in a park including a lovely group shot of grandchildren and greatgrandchildren with a grandparent
00:06:39:00 Stuart poses with a sports trophy
00:07:32:00 extended family wedding where Karen is a bridesmaid
00:08:30:00 Karen’s 21st birthday scenes where she and her brother wear matching red and white outfits and Dorothy is in a very smart dress that matches the theme
00:08:51 Karen shows off her birthday presents that are displayed on a table set up for the purpose
00:09:05:00 Karen and her new car

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film features tennis tournaments in Geelong, Ballarat and Shepparton, as well as horse riding at a family farm and attending the extended family weddings in Bellbrae and Geelong. A highlight is Karen’s 13th birthday.

Selected highights list:
00:00:38:00 Karen and Stuart in their uniforms, for Bells Park Primary School

00:03:22:00 Karen and other young tennis players
00:04:30:00 a group of cyclists ride up a hill
00:05:35:00 camping and tennis
00:06:02:00 a group of older women of the family smile for the camera
00:07:05:00 Dorothy and Stuart smile at the camera
00:07:40:00 water skiing on a river seen in the background, and swimmers in a swimming pool
00:08:19:00 a boy in the extended family poses in his pyjamas near a classic ‘Hills Hoist’ washing line at a camping and caravan park
00:08:50:00 Dorothy playing tennis
00:11:10:00 Stuart on a ‘Dragster’ bicycle
00:12:55:00 Stuart paints the family home terrace rail, followed by Les painting the house
00:13:28:00 Stuart proudly shows his new watch to the camera
00:14:33:00 horse riding
00:19:00:00 family wedding featuring a fabulous example of a 1970s dress
00:19:23:00 a member of the bridal party sporting fabulous 1970s ‘sideburns’
00:22:20:00 a row of moustaches in the bridal party

description_for_label:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film features tennis tournaments in Geelong, Ballarat and Shepparton, as well as horse riding at a family farm and attending the extended family weddings in Bellbrae and Geelong. A highlight is Karen’s 13th birthday.

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film is about family life in Geelong in the 1970s. Children Karen and Stuart have a ride on a motorbike, visits to the beach, to the ‘Bell Brae’ farm and to the snow, Karen’s 9th birthday party (filmed inside so quite dark), preparing for school, sports days and an extended family wedding. There are some great examples of 1970s fashion, particularly of the home made style.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 giving the children a ride on a motorcycle
00:00:20:00 family gathering sitting on the sand at the beach, eating ice creams

00:05:37:00 Karen’s nineth birthday party celebrations
00:05:55:00 the children riding their bikes around the house and the street, confident Karen waves to the camera
00:07:20:00 mother and daughter in the garden, Karen wearing ‘hotpants’ which were very popular in the 1970s
00:07:23:00 Karen poses for the camera in her ‘Brownies’ uniform
00:08:04:00 the grandparents of the family
00:08:58:00 Karen and Stuart ready for school
00:09:03:00 fishing off a pier
00:09:55:00 spectacular early 1970s hairstyles in preparation for one of the many family weddings
00:11:54:00 a family wedding in 1970s style
00:12:15:00 an extended family gathering
00:15:17:00 a visit to play in what might be sudden fall of snow
00:16:36:00 dad is wearing a 1970s ‘groovy’ outfit while posing with Karen and Stuart in the garden
00:17:07:00 Karen and companions do a ‘physical education’ display for the camera
00:17:57:00 Karen and Stuart pose with a blowup Santa in the garden
00:18:54:00 jet skiing at the beach

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film is a wonderful composite of the Nixon family’s life enjoying the company of their extended family at weddings, birthday gatherings and at the family holiday homes as well as on their travels to the Gold Coast, Queensland and Eildon Weir, Victoria. We see Karen turn six in the film as well as a great Christmas scene when both children are particularly excited to receive their presents, a watch for Karen and a scooter for Stuart.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 children on the beach at Portarlington
00:00:52:00 at a zoo
00:02:40:00 wedding with a tall headdress for the bride and bridesmaids in dark pink 1960s style dresses
00:04:10:00 Karen’s first day at school, in her uniform with school bag
00:04:24:00 Stuart on a trike (tricycle) saluting the camera
00:04:40:00 picnic on the beach with lots of extended family members
00:05:00:00 treasure hunt in the sand
00:06:54:00 the children on a farm tractor
00:07:20:00 the cousins of the family in a row at a driveway gate
00:08:19:00 Les, Karen and Stuart walking out of the water at the beach
00:09:49:00 children amusement park on ‘dodgem’ cars
00:11:26:00 Karen and Stuart being rowed in a rowboat, followed by a speedboat rushing past, very close to the shore
00:12:00:00 view of waterfront houses at the Gold Coast
00:12:10:00 TAA airplane taking off at an airport
00:13:27:00 extended family wedding with bridesmaids in what would have been (at the time) a very fashionable and wonderful burnt orange
00:15:28:00 Stuart receiving his Christmas scooter
00:16:00:00 Dorothy and daughter Karen in matching outfits
00:16:25:00 family members gathered under some shady trees at the beach
00:16:47:00 Karen very confidently ‘dinking’ her younger brother Stuart on his new scooter (by giving him a ride)
00:19:27:00 Dorothy and other women in the family laugh as they climb up, and fall on, a steep sand dune
00:20:13:00 Dorothy, Karen and Stuart stand outside their caravan at the beach
00:20:19:00 a family wedding, bridesmaids in purple and sporting some great examples of 1960s hairstyles
00:21:43:00 Karen’s sixth birthday party
00:22:27:00 Karen backstroking through the water
00:23:17:00 family picnic including a woman wearing a wonderful paisley shirt typical of fashion at the time
00:24:40:00 cooking on a vintage three-legged barbeque
00:26:00:00 a birthday party held at a holiday home possibly at Point Roadknight
